terminologie_extrait.definition: The mental process of seeing the serve's contact, spin, trajectory, and bounce before performing it.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Used to build consistency and precision in serve practice.

practice_serve_technique.probleme: Players practice serves mechanically without focus or visualization
practice_serve_technique.diagnostic: Rapid repetition without mental engagement prevents improvement.
causes_communes: Lack of clear model for proper serve mechanics

debutant: Watch skilled servers or coaches to model correct mechanics.
Hold the ball and practice light contact to feel spin before full serves.
intermediaire: Visualize the complete serve path — contact, spin, bounces, height — before each attempt.
Serve alone for focus, alternating visualization and execution.
avance: Use mental correction loops: visualize, execute, evaluate, then re-visualize incorporating feedback.
Train at full intensity to build whip speed and consistency.

exercices_complementaires.description: Before each serve, visualize contact, height, and bounce; record deviations after execution.

metriques_progression: Reduction in serve height error margin
Spin and placement consistency per 10 serves
erreurs_a_eviter: Rushing through balls like a factory process

short_serve_placement.probleme: Players serve short to corners and expose angles
short_serve_placement.diagnostic: Serving short to forehand or backhand opens the table and forces awkward follow-ups.
causes_communes: Lack of awareness of opponent’s angle advantage

debutant: Serve short to the middle to limit opponent’s angles.
intermediaire: Combine short-middle serves with occasional deep variations to exploit hesitation between forehand and backhand.
avance: Integrate short-middle serves into serve-and-attack strategy, using forehand follow-up positioning.

exercices_complementaires.description: Serve 10 short-middle balls focusing on depth and angle neutrality; note follow-up position.

metriques_progression: Percentage of serves keeping opponent from using wide angles
Success of forehand follow-up after middle serve
erreurs_a_eviter: Leaving ball too long when targeting middle

terminologie_extrait.definition: Interpreting the racket’s motion and contact to determine the spin type and intensity.

reading_spin.probleme: Players misread spin on serves and make unforced errors
reading_spin.diagnostic: Difficulty tracking contact point, racket direction, or differentiating spin types.
causes_communes: Failure to focus on racket at moment of contact
Lack of practice against varied spins
Overreliance on reading from ball flight alone

debutant: Focus on the racket’s direction at contact rather than entire motion.
Practice identifying spin with slow, clear serves.
intermediaire: Estimate spin using formula: racket speed minus ball speed ≈ spin level.
Take a mental snapshot at contact (‘flash video’) to memorize spin cues.
avance: Train with multi-spin servers; vary observation delay to build adaptability.
Use peripheral vision to combine cues from racket and early flight arc.

exercices_complementaires.description: Partner serves with varied spins; receiver states spin type before returning.

metriques_progression: Accuracy rate in identifying spin type
erreurs_a_eviter: Looking at ball too late after toss
Relying solely on trajectory instead of contact reading

terminologie_extrait.definition: A short, quick topspin attack against a short serve.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Used to take initiative over the table.

terminologie_extrait.definition: A hybrid stroke combining push and block motions to produce controlled backspin.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Used to return short topspin or sidespin serves.

returning_varied_serves.probleme: Players struggle to return different serve types effectively
returning_varied_serves.diagnostic: Overuse of passive pushes and lack of tactical variation.
causes_communes: Not distinguishing between short and long serves
Improper stroke choice against spin type

debutant: Attack all long serves with loop or drive instead of pushing.
Learn to differentiate short and long serves visually.
intermediaire: Use forehand flip or backhand drive on short sidespin/topspin serves.
avance: Integrate deceptive flips and quick short pushes to control rally start.
Vary depth and direction to disrupt third-ball attacks.

exercices_complementaires.description: Partner alternates serve types; receiver practices correct stroke selection for each.

metriques_progression: Percentage of successful first attacks on long serves
Error reduction rate on short serve flips
erreurs_a_eviter: Flipping too hard instead of prioritizing placement

serve_receive_control.probleme: Players return serves too aggressively or too passively
serve_receive_control.diagnostic: Neglect of controlled placement and variation makes returns predictable or error-prone.
causes_communes: Trying to win points directly on receive
Lack of focus on opponent’s positional weaknesses

debutant: Aim for consistent placement over power; keep returns low and safe.
intermediaire: Vary depth, spin, and pace while prioritizing placement to opponent’s weaker zones.
avance: Use subtle speed, spin, and angle changes to disrupt rhythm without unforced errors.

exercices_complementaires.description: Receive alternating serves and aim at three distinct table zones in sequence.

metriques_progression: Return success rate by placement zone
